#StateOpening took place here between 1941 and 1944. The Lords returned to its chamber in May 1951, 10 years after the bombing. @LordSpeaker attended a service to commemorate the bombing earlier this week
https://t.co/OVWPPP5Krm

It is 80 years since the bombing of @UKParliament during World War II, which saw the @HouseofCommons chamber destroyed. The #HouseofLords temporarily moved to the Robing Room, where a replica chamber was set up, pictured here courtesy of @UKParlArchives https://t.co/AXmeViMcGe

#HouseofLords spent 1750 hours in the chamber and grand committee checking bills, scrutinizing government and investigating public policy, with many participating online due to #COVID19. Discover more about what happens in a session of Parliament in the Lords https://t.co/w2LOXBiE2g

@LordSpeaker The #HouseofLords examines public policy and carries out investigative, subject-focused work through its committees. Recommendations in more than 200 reports published in 2019-21 include #UniversalCredit reform, banning loot boxes and tackling misinformation in a digital age
#HouseofLords checks and challenges the government’s decisions and actions in #LordsQs and urgent questions agreed by @LordSpeaker. In 2019-21 it asked more than 900 questions

In this session: the #HouseofLords revises legislation, asking the government and Commons to think again on issues such as food standards, threatening to release intimate images and scrutiny of future trade agreements
Ahead of the start of the new session at #StateOpening on Tuesday 11 May, catch up with highlights of #HouseofLords work in the 2019-21 session https://t.co/gaQZ2fBxyo https://t.co/FRYKZSq95C

The election of Lord McFall follows Lord Fowler’s announcement that he is stepping down as Lord Speaker at the end of April. Find out more about the election and see full results https://t.co/iyn7BwSaxb

The Lord Speaker oversees proceedings in the #HouseofLords chamber and plays a key role in the Lords Administration. He also acts as an ambassador for the House in the UK and abroad, explaining and promoting its work as the second chamber of @UKParliament.

Lord McFall is Senior Deputy Speaker. He starts work as Lord Speaker on 1 May. He served as MP for Dumbarton and then West Dunbartonshire, working as a whip, in Northern Ireland Office government positions and as @CommonsTreasury Chair before becoming a #HouseofLords member.

The Constitutional Reform Act 2005 ended the Lord Chancellor’s combined role as head of the judiciary, a member of the government and Speaker of the #HouseofLords. In 2006 the House held the first election for a Lord Speaker and Baroness Hayman took up office.

The Lord Speaker chairs business in the #HouseofLords chamber, plays a key role in its Administration, acts as an ambassador for the House and represents it at ceremonial occasions. The Lord Speaker is politically impartial. Find out more https://t.co/25UrudLxGy

#HouseofLords members elect the next Lord Speaker when online voting opens from Tuesday 13 April, the Clerk of the Parliaments announces the result in the chamber on Wednesday 21 April. Learn more https://t.co/iyn7BwSaxb https://t.co/YHuKiWvo81

What did the House of Lords Act 1999 achieve? 
-The Act reduced membership from 1,330 to 669
-The new law also removed the right of all but 92 hereditary Peers to sit in the House of Lords. Learn more https://t.co/MBZ9eK92fj

There is also a joint committee with members from both Houses which scrutinises the legal aspects of SIs.

Statutory Instruments (Joint Committee) https://t.co/Uc4c0ghESS

The #HouseofLords has two committees dedicated to this, each focusing on a different stage in the legislative process:

Delegated Powers and Regulatory Reform Committee 
https://t.co/V5FA9P73R4

Secondary Legislation Scrutiny Committee 
https://t.co/5H2XQ0Lx2V

The power to make delegated legislation is, as the name suggests, delegated to ministers, so SIs are subject to considerably less parliamentary control than bills. 

For this reason, it is particularly important that delegated legislation is kept under scrutiny.

Delegated or secondary legislation fills in the gaps in Acts of Parliament, providing many of the specific details & practical measures that make a law complete and enforceable. These details are provided in regulations, orders or rules & are known as statutory instruments (SIs)
